docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I read with great interest ''The Ids and Egos of Therapy Bills'' (Jan. 13) by Marek Fuchs as I had a related experience last year. I had never realized the connection of therapy and money was so concrete.
docs.abstract: Donna Golden letter on Marek Fuchs' January 13 column on therapy bills recalls unprofessional attitude of therapist who called her at work demanding payment
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I read with great interest ''The Ids and Egos of Therapy Bills'' (Jan. 13) by Marek Fuchs as I had a related experience last year.     I had never realized the connection of therapy and money was so concrete.

docs.lead_paragraph: Moving against what law enforcement officials say is a boom in ''pill mills,'' prosecutors are charging doctors with murder or manslaughter in the deaths of patients from overdoses of prescription drugs, including the powerful painkiller OxyContin. In a Florida courtroom this week, Dr. James Graves went on trial on manslaughter charges stemming from the overdose deaths of four people for whom he had prescribed OxyContin and other drugs; next month in a California state court, a similar case is to begin against Dr. Frank B. Fisher. Last year, Florida prosecutors charged Dr. Denis Deonarine with first-degree murder in connection with a fatal overdose.

headline.main: OxyContin Prescribers Face Charges in Fatal Overdoses

docs.abstract: Doctors in three similar cases in Florida and California face murder or manslaughter charges in deaths of patients from overdoses of painkiller OxyContin and other prescription narcotics; doctors hold they serve needs of low-income patients in chronic pain with aggressive techniques that reflect widely accepted medical practice; prosecutors say such doctors use changing medical views about narcotics as cover for lucrative practices in which patients pay for prescriptions, not treatment; trial of Dr James Graves, now under way in Florida, described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Moving against what law enforcement officials say is a boom in ''pill mills,'' prosecutors are charging doctors with murder or manslaughter in the deaths of patients from overdoses of prescription drugs, including the powerful painkiller OxyContin.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The head of one of the most powerful unions in New York lashed out last night at the two Democratic candidates for governor, saying that they had placed their own political ambitions ahead of the well-being of New Yorkers. The union leader, Dennis Rivera, president of the hospital workers' union and one of the most influential figures in New York Democratic Party circles, also left open the possibility that he would break with tradition and support a Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki, for re-election.

headline.main: Union Chief Assails Cuomo And McCall

docs.abstract: President of New York's hospital workers' union Dennis Rivera lashes out at two Democratic gubernatorial candidates, Andrew Cuomo and H Carl McCall, for their attacks on multibillion-dollar health care plan that includes salary increases for members of Rivera's union; contends they are putting their political ambitions ahead of well-being of people of New York; comments lead to wide speculation about whether powerful union will break with tradition of endorsing Democrats, to throw support behind incumbent Gov George Pataki; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The head of one of the most powerful unions in New York lashed out last night at the two Democratic candidates for governor, saying that they had placed their own political ambitions ahead of the well-being of New Yorkers.    The union leader, Dennis...

docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur Andersen L.L.P., the proud accounting firm nearly a century old, finds itself surrounded by angry and desperate victims of the collapse of the Enron Corporation, whose deeply flawed books it audited. Longtime corporate clients are nervously following each new report about Andersen's role in Enron's fall and the repercussions. Connecticut's attorney general has suggested that the state suspend Andersen's permit to practice there, a step that New York may follow; some Enron creditors have already filed lawsuits against the firm, and several other suits brought by Enron shareholders against Andersen look far stronger now than they did a week ago, before the firm admitted destroying documents and fired one of its auditors.
docs.abstract: Analysis of impact of Enron Corp's collapse on its auditor, Arthur Andersen LLP; firm's business could erode in crisis of confidence if too many of its clients decide its future is uncertain and switch auditors; firm has resources to combat suits from Enron creditors and shareholders; some clients say they will stand by firm; potentially at risk are thousands of jobs among firm's 85,000 employees in 84 nations; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Arthur Andersen L.L.P., the proud accounting firm nearly a century old, finds itself surrounded by angry and desperate victims of the collapse of the Enron Corporation, whose deeply flawed books it audited.    Longtime corporate clients are nervously...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 6 Killed by Palestinian At an Israeli Party A Palestinian walked into a crowded reception hall in Hadera, Israel, and opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle, killing 6 people and wounding at least 25, witnesses and the police said. A group linked to Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement took responsibility for the attack. Early today, Israeli forces bombed a Palestinian government building in Tulkarm and tanks were also reported rolling through the West Bank city of Ramallah, where Israel has effectively confined Mr. Arafat since early last month. A1 Powell Visits New Delhi Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in New Delhi expressing confidence that tensions had lessened between India and Pakistan. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: Bobby Valentine reached to his side and squeezed the right arm of the man sitting next to him. Pedro Astacio smiled and the two shared a laugh. Astacio was being introduced at Shea Stadium as the Mets' newest starting pitcher, and while Valentine's gesture was playful, it hinted at a worrisome issue for the Mets. Before the Mets try to hurdle the Atlanta Braves and the Philadelphia Phillies in the National League East, they must prove they are healthy. Astacio, the right-hander whose one-year, $5 million contract is stuffed with incentives, has a tear in the labrum in his right shoulder. He will be Valentine's No. 2 starter.

headline.main: Astacio's Health Is a Key To the Mets

docs.abstract: New York Mets introduce newly acquired pitcher Pedro Astasio; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: By everyone's account, the contracting companies excavating the tons of broken steel and smoking debris at ground zero have worked with energy and devotion. But there is one thing they have worked without -- insurance. In one of the quiet subplots of the cleanup, the giant contractors that run the cranes and trucks and work crews at the World Trade Center site have been denied the basic liability coverage against injury and property damage that builders typically carry on every project, even on a single-family house.

headline.main: Contractors at Ground Zero Denied Insurance for Cleanup

docs.abstract: Contractors that run cranes, trucks and work crews at ground zero cleanup operation have been denied basic liability coverage against injury and property damage that builders generally carry on every project; insurance companies have simply declined to provide coverage for what is deemed most dangerous job in country, contending that project is too big and risk to difficult to measure; photo (M)
docs.snippet: By everyone's account, the contracting companies excavating the tons of broken steel and smoking debris at ground zero have worked with energy and devotion. But there is one thing they have worked without -- insurance.    In one of the quiet subplots...

docs.lead_paragraph: The bulk of the Mets' work this winter has involved revamping baseball's worst offense, and they have added Roberto Alomar, Roger Cedeño and Mo Vaughn. If anything, their pitching suffered for it. Yesterday the Mets moved to bolster their starting rotation by taking a chance on a talented pitcher they have long coveted. But he came with questions regarding his health.

headline.main: Mets Gamble On Astacio For $5 Million

docs.abstract: New York Mets reach agreement with pitcher Pedro Astacio on one-year contract worth $5 million; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With each new report of possible misdeeds by professionals who worked for or with the Enron Corporation, the list of deep-pocketed potential targets of civil and criminal lawsuits resulting from the company's spectacular collapse grows longer. A variety of major companies might just end up paying damages to help compensate victims of Enron's implosion. Shareholders have already sued Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's chief executive; Jeffrey K. Skilling, its former chief executive; and members of the board, accusing them of selling stock on the basis of inside information while the company misled investors about the state of its financial health.

headline.main: A Growing Number of Potential Targets for Lawsuits

docs.abstract: List of deep-pocketed potential targets of civil and criminal lawsuits resulting from Enron Corp collapse grows with each new report of possible misdeeds by professionals who worked for or with company; variety of major companies might just end up paying damages to help compensate victims of Enron's implosion; some creditors are just starting to consider suing (M)
docs.snippet: With each new report of possible misdeeds by professionals who worked for or with the Enron Corporation, the list of deep-pocketed potential targets of civil and criminal lawsuits resulting from the company's spectacular collapse grows longer. A...

docs.lead_paragraph: Just two weeks into his mayoralty, with most of his administration in place, Michael R. Bloomberg is now offering significant clues about where his policy priorities may differ from Rudolph W. Giuliani's, on such issues as services to the poor, human rights abuses and public health. While Mr. Bloomberg's many goals will inevitably be hampered by budget constraints, observers of municipal government already see an ideological shift at City Hall. ''There is a coherence in what he is doing,'' said Douglas Muzzio, a professor of public affairs at Baruch College. ''The guy is a social liberal and he makes no bones about it. His conception of quality of life is broader and more liberal in terms of the role of the state, because it includes more stakeholders in the game.''
docs.abstract: Analysis: observers of municipal government see ideological shift at City Hall, two weeks into Michael R Bloomberg's mayoralty; see significant clues about where his policy priorities may differ from Rudolph W Giuliani's on such issues as services to poor, human rights abuses and public health; say Bloomberg's conception of quality of life is broader and more liberal in terms of role of state; note that even in pursuing Giuliani's goal of clamping down on quality-of-life crimes, Bloomberg insists, for instance, that while homeless cannot sleep on streets, shelters must have more beds and be safe; Bloomberg has expressed interest in reinvigorating areas of government that were dormant under Giuliani administration, like city's Human Rights Commission; Bloomberg's appointees have yet to make major decisions, but great many of them are Democrats; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Just two weeks into his mayoralty, with most of his administration in place, Michael R. Bloomberg is now offering significant clues about where his policy priorities may differ from Rudolph W. Giuliani's,  on such issues as services to the poor,...
